; Assembled with: nasm -f bin -o boot.bin boot.asm

%define STAGE2_SEG     0x1000        ; load segment for stage2 (phys 0x10000)
%define STAGE2_OFF     0x0000
%define STAGE2_LBA     1             ; start right after boot sector
%define STAGE2_SECTORS 128           ; adjust if stage2 grows beyond 64 KiB

BITS 16
ORG 0x7C00

start:
  cli
  xor ax, ax
  mov ds, ax
  mov es, ax
  mov ss, ax
  mov sp, 0x7C00

  mov [boot_drive], dl     ; BIOS passes boot drive in DL

  ; --- Enable A20 (fast 0x92 gate) ---
  in   al, 0x92
  or   al, 0x02
  out  0x92, al

  ; --- Load stage2 via INT 13h extensions (AH=42h) ---
  mov   si, dap
  mov   dl, [boot_drive]
  mov   ah, 0x42
  int   0x13
  jc    disk_error

  ; Jump to loaded stage2 (real mode)
  jmp   STAGE2_SEG:STAGE2_OFF

; --- Data ---
boot_drive: db 0

; Put the error string *before* the error routine to avoid forward-ref issues
err_msg db 'Disk read error',0

; Disk Address Packet (DAP) — 16 bytes (aligning to be tidy)
ALIGN 16

dap:
  db 0x10               ; size
  db 0x00               ; reserved
  dw STAGE2_SECTORS     ; sectors to read
  dw STAGE2_OFF         ; dest offset
  dw STAGE2_SEG         ; dest segment
  dd STAGE2_LBA         ; LBA low
  dd 0x00000000         ; LBA high

; --- Simple error print loop (no dotted local labels) ---

disk_error:
  mov si, err_msg
.de_print:
  lodsb
  test al, al
  jz   short .de_halt
  mov ah, 0x0E
  mov bh, 0x00
  mov bl, 0x07
  int 0x10
  jmp  short .de_print
.de_halt:
  hlt
  jmp  short .de_halt

; Boot signature *must* be the last two bytes of the 512‑byte sector
TIMES 510-($-$$) db 0
DW 0xAA55

payload.message: We’re driving the Bochs Graphics Adapter linear framebuffer, not legacy VGA. `video_hw_enable` in `video.c:115` programs the BGA registers at ports `0x1CE/0x1CF`, sets 1280×1024×16, and enables the LFB (`BGA_REG_ENABLE = 0x41`). The PCI probe in `video.c:363` also looks specifically for vendor `0x1234`, device `0x1111`, which is the Bochs/QEMU VBE device. Legacy VGA is only touched to capture/restore register state for dropping back to text mode (`video.c:464` onward).

The PCI probe in `video.c:363` also looks specifically for vendor `0x1234`, device `0x1111`, which is the Bochs/QEMU VBE device. Legacy VGA is only touched to capture/restore register state for dropping back to text mode (`video.c:464` onward).

payload.text: **Analyzing screen corruption causes on VGA switch**

summary.text: **Analyzing screen corruption causes on VGA switch**

payload.text:
**Analyzing VGA text mode corruption causes**

I’m piecing together that the vertical bars appear because switching to BGA linear framebuffer mode overwrites VGA font memory in plane 2, which isn’t restored on return to text mode. The framebuffer writes to VRAM corrupt the font glyphs, so when the code restores only VGA registers without reloading fonts, the text shows as bars. This matches what I see around `video_enter_mode` writing to the framebuffer (`video.c:156`), restoring VGA registers without fonts (`video.c:520`), and console writes to 0xB8000 (`console.c:18`). To fix this, saving and restoring the VGA font memory before and after graphics mode is needed, or loading fonts via BIOS calls—though BIOS calls aren’t possible in long mode. Let’s explain this thoroughly with these references.

payload.message: The corruption fits with us trampling the BIOS text-mode font while in Bochs BGA graphics mode. `video_enter_mode` switches to the BGA linear framebuffer and immediately paints the whole surface (`video.c:247`, clears at `video.c:156`). That linear framebuffer is just a different window onto the same VRAM bank that also holds the VGA font bitmaps. Once we’ve filled it with 16‑bit pixels, the font data in plane 2 is gone. When we exit, `video_exit_mode` merely disables BGA and reapplies the saved VGA register set (`video.c:288`, `video.c:522`). Registers alone aren’t enough—text output depends on the character glyphs still sitting in VRAM. So, when `console_clear` and other console writes push character codes/attributes back to 0xB8000 (`console.c:9`, `console.c:36`), the hardware renders whatever garbage now lives in the font plane, which shows up as those vertical bars while the cursor still moves. To fix it we need to cache the text-mode font before entering graphics and restore it (or otherwise reload a known font) when we return to text mode.

The framebuffer writes to VRAM corrupt the font glyphs, so when the code restores only VGA registers without reloading fonts, the text shows as bars. This matches what I see around `video_enter_mode` writing to the framebuffer (`video.c:156`), restoring VGA registers without fonts (`video.c:520`), and console writes to 0xB8000 (`console.c:18`). To fix this, saving and restoring the VGA font memory before and after graphics mode is needed, or loading fonts via BIOS calls—though BIOS calls aren’t possible in long mode. Let’s explain this thoroughly with these references.

content.text: The corruption fits with us trampling the BIOS text-mode font while in Bochs BGA graphics mode. `video_enter_mode` switches to the BGA linear framebuffer and immediately paints the whole surface (`video.c:247`, clears at `video.c:156`). That linear framebuffer is just a different window onto the same VRAM bank that also holds the VGA font bitmaps. Once we’ve filled it with 16‑bit pixels, the font data in plane 2 is gone. When we exit, `video_exit_mode` merely disables BGA and reapplies the saved VGA register set (`video.c:288`, `video.c:522`). Registers alone aren’t enough—text output depends on the character glyphs still sitting in VRAM. So, when `console_clear` and other console writes push character codes/attributes back to 0xB8000 (`console.c:9`, `console.c:36`), the hardware renders whatever garbage now lives in the font plane, which shows up as those vertical bars while the cursor still moves. To fix it we need to cache the text-mode font before entering graphics and restore it (or otherwise reload a known font) when we return to text mode.

payload.text:
**Planning VGA font capture and restore**

I’m mapping out a detailed plan to implement saving and restoring the VGA text-mode font by manipulating VGA sequencer and graphics controller registers. The idea is to capture the font data from VGA plane 2 before switching to graphics mode and restore it upon returning to text mode, handling register state carefully to avoid glitches. It’s quite intricate, involving port I/O commands and memory access at 0xA0000, so I’ll define helper functions to read/write VGA registers and store the font in a static buffer with flags to avoid redundant captures. I want to ensure the process fits cleanly into the existing video initialization and mode switching flow. This will take some precise programming to replicate standard VGA font handling inside a 64-bit long mode kernel environment.

**Designing detailed font capture and restore functions**

I’m working out the full implementation of functions to capture and restore the VGA font by carefully saving VGA register states, configuring VGA planes for access, copying font bytes from memory at 0xA0000, and then restoring all registers to their original text mode states. To keep things reliable, I plan to save the original register values, switch to plane 2 access mode with precise register writes, read or write the font buffer, and afterwards restore the registers fully using the saved state. This approach also includes integrating the font capture call into `video_init` after capturing VGA regs, and calling font restore after exiting graphics mode to reestablish the text mode font. The plan accounts for 8192 bytes of font data for 256 or 512 characters, aiming for robustness during mode transitions in a 64-bit long mode kernel environment.

**Planning reliable font save and restore integration**

I’m mapping out how to properly sequence calls so `vga_capture_font()` runs only after VGA state is captured, ensuring saved registers are ready for restoration. This involves creating helper functions to read/write VGA sequencer and graphics controller registers, defining a small struct to hold saved register values, and implementing `vga_font_access_begin` and `vga_font_access_end` to set and restore VGA registers around font memory access. I’m also figuring out where to call `vga_restore_font` safely after re-entering text mode, possibly modifying `vga_enter_text_mode` to restore fonts when state restoration succeeds. Throughout, I’ll incorporate checks to avoid capturing fonts prematurely and add logging to trace the process.

**Summarizing final response details**

I'll craft a clear final message explaining the key change: capturing and restoring the VGA font to prevent glyph corruption when switching modes. The message will include bullet points referencing specific code lines like `video.c:47`, `video.c:79`, and mention running `make` for testing. payload.message:
Captured the text-mode font before touching the Bochs framebuffer and restore it after shutting video mode down so glyphs survive the round-trip.

**Key Changes**
- Added persistent font storage and register snapshot helpers to safely read/write VGA plane 2 (`video.c:47`, `video.c:470`).
- Cache the BIOS font during init so it’s preserved before the LFB gets filled (`video.c:79`, `video.c:607`).
- Restore the saved font whenever we return to text mode, reusing the original VGA register state (`video.c:634`, `video.c:655`).

**Tests**
- `make`

**Next Steps**
1. Boot and run `start_video`, then exit back to the shell to confirm text renders normally.

payload.message:
The crash was our fault: the old static `backbuffer` lived in `.bss`, so it grew the kernel’s zero-initialized data past 0x70000. That region is where stage2 builds the page tables, so every draw pass was trampling critical paging structures and QEMU promptly triple-faulted.

Fixes in place:

- Parked the back buffer in a safe chunk of identity-mapped RAM (`video.c:48-49`). We now treat it as a pointer to 0x0020_0000, well clear of the page tables.
- Everything else (dirty rect logic, blitting) still targets the buffer through that pointer, so no behavioural changes were needed (`video.c:326-528`, `video.c:739-884`).

Rebuild with `make` (done) and re-run `make run-hdd`; QEMU should stay up again. If you prefer a different back-buffer address later, just tweak `BACKBUFFER_ADDR` and keep it away from the page-table scratch space.

Fixes in place:

- Everything else (dirty rect logic, blitting) still targets the buffer through that pointer, so no behavioural changes were needed (`video.c:326-528`, `video.c:739-884`).

Rebuild with `make` (done) and re-run `make run-hdd`; QEMU should stay up again. If you prefer a different back-buffer address later, just tweak `BACKBUFFER_ADDR` and keep it away from the page-table scratch space.

- Taught `keyboard_try_read` to ignore PS/2 mouse bytes by checking the controller status for the mouse-data bit before touching port 0x60 (`keyboard.c:16`). That keeps mouse packets from being misread as scancodes when you’re back in text mode.

Tests: `make`

If you still see odd chars, try moving the mouse with interrupts disabled to confirm no packets leak; otherwise we can look into buffering multiple mouse bytes.

{"output":"NASM     := nasm
CC       := x86_64-elf-gcc
LD       := x86_64-elf-ld
OBJCOPY  := x86_64-elf-objcopy
QEMU     := qemu-system-x86_64

CFLAGS := -std=c11 -ffreestanding -fno-stack-protector -fno-builtin -fno-pic \
          -m64 -mno-red-zone -mgeneral-regs-only -Wall -Wextra -Iinclude

STAGE2_OBJS := stage2.o kernel.o console.o serial.o keyboard.o vfs.o libc.o \
                idt.o interrupts.o timer.o mouse.o video.o

all: os.img

boot.bin: boot.asm
	$(NASM) -f bin -o $@ $<

stage2.o: stage2.asm
	$(NASM) -f elf64 -o $@ $<

%.o: %.c
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

stage2.elf: $(STAGE2_OBJS) stage2.ld
	$(LD) -nostdlib -T stage2.ld -o $@ $(STAGE2_OBJS)

stage2.bin: stage2.elf
	$(OBJCOPY) -O binary $< $@

# 1.44MB **floppy/drive** image (NOT an ISO/CD)
os.img: boot.bin stage2.bin
	@# Create a 1.44MB floppy image
	dd if=/dev/zero of=$@ bs=512 count=2880 2>/dev/null
	dd if=boot.bin   of=$@ conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
	dd if=stage2.bin of=$@ bs=512 seek=1 conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null

# Optional: small HDD-style image (no partition table, boots from LBA0 directly)
hdd.img: boot.bin stage2.bin
	dd if=/dev/zero of=$@ bs=1M count=16 2>/dev/null
	dd if=boot.bin   of=$@ conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
	dd if=stage2.bin of=$@ bs=512 seek=1 conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null

run: os.img
	$(QEMU) -fda os.img -boot a -no-reboot -serial mon:stdio

run-hdd: hdd.img
	$(QEMU) -drive file=hdd.img,format=raw,if=ide -no-reboot -serial mon:stdio

clean:
	rm -f boot.bin stage2.bin stage2.o stage2.elf \
	      $(STAGE2_OBJS) os.img hdd.img
","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.3}}

+NASM     := nasm
+CC       := x86_64-elf-gcc
+LD       := x86_64-elf-ld
+OBJCOPY  := x86_64-elf-objcopy
+QEMU     := qemu-system-x86_64
+
+SRC_DIR     := src
+ARCH_DIR    := $(SRC_DIR)/arch/x86
+KERNEL_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/kernel
+DRIVER_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/drivers
+INCLUDE_DIR := include
+OBJDIR      := build
+
+CFLAGS := -std=c11 -ffreestanding -fno-stack-protector -fno-builtin -fno-pic \
+          -m64 -mno-red-zone -mgeneral-regs-only -Wall -Wextra -I$(INCLUDE_DIR)
+
+BOOT_SRC    := $(ARCH_DIR)/boot.asm
+STAGE2_SRC  := $(ARCH_DIR)/stage2.asm
+STAGE2_LD   := $(ARCH_DIR)/stage2.ld
+
+C_SOURCES := \
+	$(wildcard $(KERNEL_DIR)/*.c) \
+	$(wildcard $(DRIVER_DIR)/*.c) \
+	$(wildcard $(ARCH_DIR)/*.c)
+
+C_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.c,$(OBJDIR)/%.o,$(C_SOURCES))
+
+STAGE2_OBJ := $(OBJDIR)/arch/x86/stage2.o
+STAGE2_OBJS := $(STAGE2_OBJ) $(C_OBJECTS)
+
+BOOT_BIN   := $(OBJDIR)/boot.bin
+STAGE2_ELF := $(OBJDIR)/stage2.elf
+STAGE2_BIN := $(OBJDIR)/stage2.bin
+
+all: os.img
+
+$(OBJDIR)/%.o: $(SRC_DIR)/%.c
+	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
+	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<
+
+$(STAGE2_OBJ): $(STAGE2_SRC)
+	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
+	$(NASM) -f elf64 -o $@ $<
+
+$(BOOT_BIN): $(BOOT_SRC)
+	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
+	$(NASM) -f bin -o $@ $<
+
+$(STAGE2_ELF): $(STAGE2_OBJS) $(STAGE2_LD)
+	$(LD) -nostdlib -T $(STAGE2_LD) -o $@ $(STAGE2_OBJS)
+
+$(STAGE2_BIN): $(STAGE2_ELF)
+	$(OBJCOPY) -O binary $< $@
+
+# 1.44MB **floppy/drive** image (NOT an ISO/CD)
+os.img: $(BOOT_BIN) $(STAGE2_BIN)
+	@# Create a 1.44MB floppy image
+	dd if=/dev/zero of=$@ bs=512 count=2880 2>/dev/null
+	dd if=$(BOOT_BIN)   of=$@ conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
+	dd if=$(STAGE2_BIN) of=$@ bs=512 seek=1 conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
+
+# Optional: small HDD-style image (no partition table, boots from LBA0 directly)
+hdd.img: $(BOOT_BIN) $(STAGE2_BIN)
+	dd if=/dev/zero of=$@ bs=1M count=16 2>/dev/null
+	dd if=$(BOOT_BIN)   of=$@ conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
+	dd if=$(STAGE2_BIN) of=$@ bs=512 seek=1 conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
+
+run: os.img
+	$(QEMU) -fda os.img -boot a -no-reboot -serial mon:stdio
+
+run-hdd: hdd.img
+	$(QEMU) -drive file=hdd.img,format=raw,if=ide -no-reboot -serial mon:stdio
+
+clean:
+	rm -rf $(OBJDIR) os.img hdd.img
*** End Patch

payload.message:
- Added a reusable button system (styles, callbacks, relative/absolute placement) and per-window child arrays so UI controls can live inside windows (`src/drivers/video.c:68-139`, `src/drivers/video.c:790-849`).
- Implemented button drawing, hit-testing, and dirty tracking plus desktop rendering so window controls and desktop icons paint correctly without flicker (`src/drivers/video.c:452-609`).
- Every new window now spawns an “X” title-bar button wired to a close action, and window reordering/closing keeps drag/button state in sync (`src/drivers/video.c:818-912`, `src/drivers/video.c:1008-1078`).
- Replaced the double-click exit with draggable desktop icon buttons (including an Exit icon) and rewrote mouse handling to route presses/releases to buttons, window drags, or desktop icon drags/actions (`src/drivers/video.c:1083-1435`).
- Tests: `make`

Next up, consider adding more desktop icon actions (e.g., launch new window types) using the new button hooks.

payload.text:
**Designing UI and video module separation**

I'm drafting a plan to move all UI-related logic and data from the video module into a new ATK module that handles windows, buttons, and colors. This includes defining clear interfaces so video manages hardware and low-level drawing, while ATK handles UI state, rendering, and input events. I'll create new APIs for initializing, event handling, rendering, and marking dirty regions, ensuring clean dependency flow and modularity. This restructuring should simplify the video code and centralize UI concerns in ATK.

**Refactoring event handling and APIs**

I'm detailing how mouse event handling now resets dirty state, calls ATK’s handler which signals if redraw or exit is needed, then triggers full UI re-rendering and flushes updated regions. This involves expanding video.h with new exposed drawing and interface functions, renaming many static video functions to public ones used by ATK, and removing UI-specific code from video.c. I’m also planning the ATK module’s implementation with UI state and rendering, ensuring a clean split and smooth communication between video and ATK layers.

**Finalizing exit logic and build integration**

I'm nailing down the exit flag flow via ATK’s mouse event result and cleaning up logging and old UI remnants in video.c. Then I’ll update headers and the Makefile to add the new ATK source directory so the build system compiles the new UI module alongside existing code. This wraps up the modular UI refactor and prepares for building and testing.

{"command":["bash","-lc","python3 - <<'PY'
from pathlib import Path
path = Path('src/drivers/video.c')
text = path.read_text()
start = text.find('static void button_set_title')
end = text.find('bool video_enter_mode')
if start == -1 or end == -1 or end <= start:
    raise SystemExit('Unable to locate code block for removal')
new_text = text[:start] + text[end:]
path.write_text(new_text)
PY
"],"workdir":"/Users/alex/Documents/Projects/alix"}

{"output":"NASM     := nasm
CC       := x86_64-elf-gcc
LD       := x86_64-elf-ld
OBJCOPY  := x86_64-elf-objcopy
QEMU     := qemu-system-x86_64

SRC_DIR     := src
ARCH_DIR    := $(SRC_DIR)/arch/x86
KERNEL_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/kernel
DRIVER_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/drivers
INCLUDE_DIR := include
OBJDIR      := build

CFLAGS := -std=c11 -ffreestanding -fno-stack-protector -fno-builtin -fno-pic \
          -m64 -mno-red-zone -mgeneral-regs-only -Wall -Wextra -I$(INCLUDE_DIR)

BOOT_SRC    := $(ARCH_DIR)/boot.asm
STAGE2_SRC  := $(ARCH_DIR)/stage2.asm
STAGE2_LD   := $(ARCH_DIR)/stage2.ld

C_SOURCES := \
	$(wildcard $(KERNEL_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(DRIVER_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(ARCH_DIR)/*.c)

C_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.c,$(OBJDIR)/%.o,$(C_SOURCES))

STAGE2_OBJ := $(OBJDIR)/arch/x86/stage2.o
STAGE2_OBJS := $(STAGE2_OBJ) $(C_OBJECTS)

BOOT_BIN   := $(OBJDIR)/boot.bin
STAGE2_ELF := $(OBJDIR)/stage2.elf
STAGE2_BIN := $(OBJDIR)/stage2.bin

all: os.img

$(OBJDIR)/%.o: $(SRC_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(STAGE2_OBJ): $(STAGE2_SRC)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(NASM) -f elf64 -o $@ $<

$(BOOT_BIN): $(BOOT_SRC)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(NASM) -f bin -o $@ $<

$(STAGE2_ELF): $(STAGE2_OBJS) $(STAGE2_LD)
	$(LD) -nostdlib -T $(STAGE2_LD) -o $@ $(STAGE2_OBJS)

$(STAGE2_BIN): $(STAGE2_ELF)
	$(OBJCOPY) -O binary $< $@

# 1.44MB **floppy/drive** image (NOT an ISO/CD)
os.img: $(BOOT_BIN) $(STAGE2_BIN)
	@# Create a 1.44MB floppy image
	dd if=/dev/zero of=$@ bs=512 count=2880 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(BOOT_BIN)   of=$@ conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(STAGE2_BIN) of=$@ bs=512 seek=1 conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null

# Optional: small HDD-style image (no partition table, boots from LBA0 directly)
hdd.img: $(BOOT_BIN) $(STAGE2_BIN)
	dd if=/dev/zero of=$@ bs=1M count=16 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(BOOT_BIN)   of=$@ conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(STAGE2_BIN) of=$@ bs=512 seek=1 conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null

run: os.img
	$(QEMU) -fda os.img -boot a -no-reboot -serial mon:stdio

run-hdd: hdd.img
	$(QEMU) -drive file=hdd.img,format=raw,if=ide -no-reboot -serial mon:stdio

clean:
	rm -rf $(OBJDIR) os.img hdd.img
","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.2}}

payload.text:
**Summarizing final message details**

I’m gathering all the key updates for the final message: how video UI functions now delegate to the ATK layer, new drawing primitives, Makefile changes, and test results. payload.message:
- Reshaped `video.c` into a pure rendering/driver layer: it now exports drawing + dirty-rect helpers (`video_fill`, `video_draw_rect*`, `video_draw_text`, `video_invalidate_rect`) and delegates mode entry/exit and mouse routing to ATK (`src/drivers/video.c:192-520`).
- Published those primitives via `include/video.h:6-21`, letting higher layers build UI without touching VGA internals.
- Introduced the Alix Tool Kit: `include/atk.h:6-15` declares the UI surface, and `src/atk/atk.c:1-512` owns windows, buttons, desktop icons, and mouse hit-testing; it now raises redraw/exit requests back to the driver and renders through the new video API.
- Build now compiles the new toolkit directory with an updated source list (`Makefile:8-24`).

Tests:
- `make clean && make`

content.text:
- Reshaped `video.c` into a pure rendering/driver layer: it now exports drawing + dirty-rect helpers (`video_fill`, `video_draw_rect*`, `video_draw_text`, `video_invalidate_rect`) and delegates mode entry/exit and mouse routing to ATK (`src/drivers/video.c:192-520`).
- Published those primitives via `include/video.h:6-21`, letting higher layers build UI without touching VGA internals.
- Introduced the Alix Tool Kit: `include/atk.h:6-15` declares the UI surface, and `src/atk/atk.c:1-512` owns windows, buttons, desktop icons, and mouse hit-testing; it now raises redraw/exit requests back to the driver and renders through the new video API.
- Build now compiles the new toolkit directory with an updated source list (`Makefile:8-24`).

Tests:
- `make clean && make`
